column2: CHAPTER VII
column3: CHAPTER seven

column2: THE SECOND VOYAGE OF SINDBAD THE SAILOR
column3: THE SECOND VOYAGE OF SINDBAD THE SAILOR

column2: I designed, after my first voyage, to spend the rest of my days at Bagdad, but it was not long ere I grew weary of an indolent life, and I put to sea a second time, with merchants of known probity.
column3: I designed, after my first voyage, to spend the rest of my days at Bagdad, but it was not long ere I grew weary of an indolent life, and I put to sea a second time, with merchants of known probity.

column2: We embarked on board a good ship, and, after recommending ourselves to God, set sail.
column3: We embarked on board a good ship, and, after recommending ourselves to God, set sail.

column2: We traded from island to island, and exchanged commodities with great profit.
column3: We traded from island to island, and exchanged commodities with great profit.

column2: One day we landed on an island covered with several sorts of fruit trees, but we could see neither man nor animal.
column3: One day we landed on an island covered with several sorts of fruit trees, but we could see neither man nor animal.

column2: We walked in the meadows, along the streams that watered them.
column3: We walked in the meadows, along the streams that watered them.

column2: While some diverted themselves with gathering flowers, and others fruits, I took my wine and provisions, and sat down near a stream betwixt two high trees, which formed a thick shade.
column3: While some diverted themselves with gathering flowers, and others fruits, I took my wine and provisions, and sat down near a stream betwixt two high trees, which formed a thick shade.

column2: I made a good meal, and afterward fell asleep.
column3: I made a good meal, and afterward fell asleep.

column2: I cannot tell how long I slept, but when I awoke the ship was gone.
column3: I cannot tell how long I slept, but when I awoke the ship was gone.

column2: In this sad condition, I was ready to die with grief.
column3: In this sad condition, I was ready to die with grief.

column2: I cried out in agony, beat my head and breast, and threw myself upon the ground, where I lay some time in despair.
column3: I cried out in agony, beat my head and breast, and threw myself upon the ground, where I lay some time in despair.

column2: I upbraided myself a hundred times for not being content with the produce of my first voyage, that might have sufficed me all my life.
column3: I upbraided myself a hundred times for not being content with the produce of my first voyage, that might have sufficed me all my life.

column2: But all this was in vain, and my repentance came too late.
column3: But all this was in vain, and my repentance came too late.

column2: At last I resigned myself to the will of God.
column3: At last I resigned myself to the will of God.

column2: Not knowing what to do, I climbed up to the top of a lofty tree, from whence I looked about on all sides, to see if I could discover anything that could give me hopes.
column3: Not knowing what to do, I climbed up to the top of a lofty tree, from whence I looked about on all sides, to see if I could discover anything that could give me hopes.

column2: When I gazed toward the sea I could see nothing but sky and water; but looking over the land, I beheld something white; and coming down, I took what provision I had left and went toward it, the distance being so great, that I could not distinguish what it was.
column3: When I gazed toward the sea I could see nothing but sky and water; but looking over the land, I beheld something white; and coming down, I took what provision I had left and went toward it, the distance being so great, that I could not distinguish what it was.

column2: As I approached, I thought it to be a white dome, of a prodigious height and extent; and when I came up to it, I touched it, and found it to be very smooth.
column3: As I approached, I thought it to be a white dome, of a prodigious height and extent; and when I came up to it, I touched it, and found it to be very smooth.

column2: I went round to see if it was open on any side, but saw it was not, and that there was no climbing up to the top, as it was so smooth.
column3: I went round to see if it was open on any side, but saw it was not, and that there was no climbing up to the top, as it was so smooth.

column2: It was at least fifty paces round.
column3: It was at least fifty paces round.

column2: By this time the sun was about to set, and all of a sudden the sky became as dark as if it had been covered with a thick cloud.
column3: By this time the sun was about to set, and all of a sudden the sky became as dark as if it had been covered with a thick cloud.

column2: I was much astonished at this sudden darkness, but much more when I found it occasioned by a bird of a monstrous size, that came flying toward me.
column3: I was much astonished at this sudden darkness, but much more when I found it occasioned by a bird of a monstrous size, that came flying toward me.

column2: I remembered that I had often heard mariners speak of a miraculous bird called the Roc, and conceived that the great dome which I so much admired must be its egg.
column3: I remembered that I had often heard mariners speak of a miraculous bird called the Roc, and conceived that the great dome which I so much admired must be its egg.

column2: In short, the bird alighted, and sat over the egg.
column3: In short, the bird alighted, and sat over the egg.

column2: As I perceived her coming, I crept close to the egg, so that I had before me one of the legs of the bird, which was as big as the trunk of a tree.
column3: As I perceived her coming, I crept close to the egg, so that I had before me one of the legs of the bird, which was as big as the trunk of a tree.

column2: I tied myself strongly to it with my turban, in hopes that the roc next morning would carry me with her out of this desert island. After having passed the night in this condition, the bird flew away as soon as it was daylight, and carried me so high, that I could not discern the earth; she afterward descended with so much rapidity that I lost my senses.
column3: I tied myself strongly to it with my turban, in hopes that the roc next morning would carry me with her out of this desert island. After having passed the night in this condition, the bird flew away as soon as it was daylight, and carried me so high, that I could not discern the earth; she afterward descended with so much rapidity that I lost my senses.

column2: But when I found myself on the ground, I speedily untied the knot, and had scarcely done so, when the roc, having taken up a serpent of a monstrous length in her bill, flew away.
column3: But when I found myself on the ground, I speedily untied the knot, and had scarcely done so, when the roc, having taken up a serpent of a monstrous length in her bill, flew away.

column2: The spot where it left me was encompassed on all sides by mountains, that seemed to reach above the clouds, and so steep that there was no possibility of getting out of the valley.
column3: The spot where it left me was encompassed on all sides by mountains, that seemed to reach above the clouds, and so steep that there was no possibility of getting out of the valley.

column2: This was a new perplexity; so that when I compared this place with the desert island from which the roc had brought me, I found that I had gained nothing by the change.
column3: This was a new perplexity; so that when I compared this place with the desert island from which the roc had brought me, I found that I had gained nothing by the change.

column2: As I walked through this valley, I perceived it was strewed with diamonds, some of which were of surprising bigness.
column3: As I walked through this valley, I perceived it was strewed with diamonds, some of which were of surprising bigness.

column2: I took pleasure in looking upon them; but shortly saw at a distance such objects as greatly diminished my satisfaction, and which I could not view without terror, namely, a great number of serpents, so monstrous that the least of them was capable of swallowing an elephant.
column3: I took pleasure in looking upon them; but shortly saw at a distance such objects as greatly diminished my satisfaction, and which I could not view without terror, namely, a great number of serpents, so monstrous that the least of them was capable of swallowing an elephant.

column2: They retired in the day-time to their dens, where they hid themselves from the roc, their enemy, and came out only in the night.
column3: They retired in the day-time to their dens, where they hid themselves from the roc, their enemy, and came out only in the night.

column2: I spent the day in walking about in the valley, resting myself at times in such places as I thought most convenient.
column3: I spent the day in walking about in the valley, resting myself at times in such places as I thought most convenient.

column2: When night came on I went into I cave, where I thought I might repose in safety.
column3: When night came on I went into I cave, where I thought I might repose in safety.

column2: I secured the entrance, which was low and narrow, with a great stone, to preserve me from the serpents; but not so far as to exclude the light.
column3: I secured the entrance, which was low and narrow, with a great stone, to preserve me from the serpents; but not so far as to exclude the light.

column2: I supped on part of my provisions, but the serpents, which began hissing round me, put me into such extreme fear that I did not sleep.
column3: I supped on part of my provisions, but the serpents, which began hissing round me, put me into such extreme fear that I did not sleep.

column2: When day appeared the serpents retired, and I came out of the cave trembling.
column3: When day appeared the serpents retired, and I came out of the cave trembling.

column2: I can justly say that I walked upon diamonds without feeling any inclination to touch them.
column3: I can justly say that I walked upon diamonds without feeling any inclination to touch them.

column2: At last I sat down, and notwithstanding my apprehensions, not having closed my eyes during the night, fell asleep, after having eaten a little more of my provisions.
column3: At last I sat down, and notwithstanding my apprehensions, not having closed my eyes during the night, fell asleep, after having eaten a little more of my provisions.

column2: But I had scarcely shut my eyes when something that fell by me with a great noise awaked me.
column3: But I had scarcely shut my eyes when something that fell by me with a great noise awaked me.

column2: This was a large piece of raw meat; and at the same time I saw several others fall down from the rocks in different places.
column3: This was a large piece of raw meat; and at the same time I saw several others fall down from the rocks in different places.

column2: I had always regarded as fabulous what I had heard sailors and others relate of the valley of diamonds, and of the stratagems employed by merchants to obtain jewels from thence; but now I found that they had stated nothing but the truth.
column3: I had always regarded as fabulous what I had heard sailors and others relate of the valley of diamonds, and of the stratagems employed by merchants to obtain jewels from thence; but now I found that they had stated nothing but the truth.

column2: For the fact is, that the merchants come to the neighbourhood of this valley, when the eagles have young ones, and throwing great joints of meat into the valley, the diamonds, upon whose points they fall, stick to them; the eagles, which are stronger in this country than anywhere else, pounce with great force upon those pieces of meat, and carry them to their nests on the precipices of the rocks to feed their young: the merchants at this time run to their nests, disturb and drive off the eagles by their shouts, and take away the diamonds that stick to the meat.
column3: For the fact is, that the merchants come to the neighbourhood of this valley, when the eagles have young ones, and throwing great joints of meat into the valley, the diamonds, upon whose points they fall, stick to them; the eagles, which are stronger in this country than anywhere else, pounce with great force upon those pieces of meat, and carry them to their nests on the precipices of the rocks to feed their young: the merchants at this time run to their nests, disturb and drive off the eagles by their shouts, and take away the diamonds that stick to the meat.

column2: I perceived in this device the means of my deliverance.
column3: I perceived in this device the means of my deliverance.

column2: Having collected together the largest diamonds I could find, I put them into the leather bag in which I used to carry my provisions, I took the largest of the pieces of meat, tied it close round me with the cloth of my turban, and then laid myself upon the ground, with my face downward, the bag of diamonds being made fast to my girdle.
column3: Having collected together the largest diamonds I could find, I put them into the leather bag in which I used to carry my provisions, I took the largest of the pieces of meat, tied it close round me with the cloth of my turban, and then laid myself upon the ground, with my face downward, the bag of diamonds being made fast to my girdle.

column2: I had scarcely placed myself in this posture when one of the eagles, having taken me up with the piece of meat to which I was fastened, carried me to his nest on the top of the mountain.
column3: I had scarcely placed myself in this posture when one of the eagles, having taken me up with the piece of meat to which I was fastened, carried me to his nest on the top of the mountain.

column2: The merchants immediately began their shouting to frighten the eagles; and when they had obliged them to quit their prey, one of them came to the nest where I was.
column3: The merchants immediately began their shouting to frighten the eagles; and when they had obliged them to quit their prey, one of them came to the nest where I was.

column2: He was much alarmed when he saw me; but recovering himself, instead of inquiring how I came thither, began to quarrel with me, and asked why I stole his goods?
column3: He was much alarmed when he saw me; but recovering himself, instead of inquiring how I came thither, began to quarrel with me, and asked why I stole his goods?

column2: You will treat me, replied I, "with more civility, when you know me better.
column3: You will treat me, replied I, "with more civility, when you know me better.

column2: Do not be uneasy; I have diamonds enough for you and myself, more than all the other merchants together. Whatever they have they owe to chance; but I selected for myself, in the bottom of the valley, those which you see in this bag," I had scarcely done speaking, when the other merchants came crowding about us, much astonished to see me; but they were much more surprised when I told them my story.
column3: Do not be uneasy; I have diamonds enough for you and myself, more than all the other merchants together. Whatever they have they owe to chance; but I selected for myself, in the bottom of the valley, those which you see in this bag," I had scarcely done speaking, when the other merchants came crowding about us, much astonished to see me; but they were much more surprised when I told them my story.

column2: They conducted me to their encampment; and there having opened my bag, they were surprised at the largeness of my diamonds, and confessed that they had never seen any of such size and perfection.
column3: They conducted me to their encampment; and there having opened my bag, they were surprised at the largeness of my diamonds, and confessed that they had never seen any of such size and perfection.

column2: I prayed the merchant who owned the nest to which I had been carried (for every merchant had his own) to take as many for his share as he pleased.
column3: I prayed the merchant who owned the nest to which I had been carried (for every merchant had his own) to take as many for his share as he pleased.

column2: He contented himself with one, and that, too, the least of them; and when I pressed him to take more, without fear of doing me any injury, "No," said he, "I am very well satisfied with this, which is valuable enough to save me the trouble of making any more voyages, and will raise as great a fortune as I desire."
column3: He contented himself with one, and that, too, the least of them; and when I pressed him to take more, without fear of doing me any injury, "No," said he, "I am very well satisfied with this, which is valuable enough to save me the trouble of making any more voyages, and will raise as great a fortune as I desire."

column2: I spent the night with the merchants, to whom I related my story a second time, for the satisfaction of those who had not heard it, I could not moderate my joy when I found myself delivered from the danger I have mentioned.
column3: I spent the night with the merchants, to whom I related my story a second time, for the satisfaction of those who had not heard it, I could not moderate my joy when I found myself delivered from the danger I have mentioned.

column2: I thought myself in a dream, and could scarcely believe myself out of danger.
column3: I thought myself in a dream, and could scarcely believe myself out of danger.

column2: The merchants had thrown their pieces of meat into the valley for several days; and each of them being satisfied with the diamonds that had fallen to his lot, we left the place the next morning, and travelled near high mountains, where there were serpents of a prodigious length, which we had the good fortune to escape.
column3: The merchants had thrown their pieces of meat into the valley for several days; and each of them being satisfied with the diamonds that had fallen to his lot, we left the place the next morning, and travelled near high mountains, where there were serpents of a prodigious length, which we had the good fortune to escape.

column2: We took shipping at the first port we reached, and touched at the isle of Roha, where the trees grow that yield camphire.
column3: We took shipping at the first port we reached, and touched at the isle of Roha, where the trees grow that yield camphire.

column2: This tree is so large, and its branches so thick, that one hundred men may easily sit under its shade.
column3: This tree is so large, and its branches so thick, that one hundred men may easily sit under its shade.

column2: The juice, of which the camphire is made, exudes from a hole bored in the upper part of the tree, and is received in a vessel, where it thickens to a consistency, and becomes what we call camphire.
column3: The juice, of which the camphire is made, exudes from a hole bored in the upper part of the tree, and is received in a vessel, where it thickens to a consistency, and becomes what we call camphire.

column2: After the juice is thus drawn out, the tree withers and dies.
column3: After the juice is thus drawn out, the tree withers and dies.

column2: In this island is also found the rhinoceros, an animal less than the elephant, but larger than the buffalo.
column3: In this island is also found the rhinoceros, an animal less than the elephant, but larger than the buffalo.

column2: It has a horn upon its nose, about a cubit in length; this horn is solid, and cleft through the middle.
column3: It has a horn upon its nose, about a cubit in length; this horn is solid, and cleft through the middle.

column2: The rhinoceros fights with the elephant, runs his horn into his belly, and carries him off upon his head; but the blood and the fat of the elephant running into his eyes and making him blind, he falls to the ground; and then, strange to relate, the roc comes and carries them both away in her claws, for food for her young ones.
column3: The rhinoceros fights with the elephant, runs his horn into his belly, and carries him off upon his head; but the blood and the fat of the elephant running into his eyes and making him blind, he falls to the ground; and then, strange to relate, the roc comes and carries them both away in her claws, for food for her young ones.

column2: I pass over many other things peculiar to this island, lest I should weary you.
column3: I pass over many other things peculiar to this island, lest I should weary you.

column2: Here I exchanged some of my diamonds for merchandise.
column3: Here I exchanged some of my diamonds for merchandise.

column2: From hence we went to other islands, and at last, having touched at several trading towns of the continent, we landed at Bussorah, from whence I proceeded to Bagdad.
column3: From hence we went to other islands, and at last, having touched at several trading towns of the continent, we landed at Bussorah, from whence I proceeded to Bagdad.

column2: There I immediately gave large presents to the poor, and lived honourably upon the vast riches I had brought, and gained with so much fatigue.
column3: There I immediately gave large presents to the poor, and lived honourably upon the vast riches I had brought, and gained with so much fatigue.

column2: Thus Sindbad ended the relation of the second voyage, gave Hindbad another hundred sequins, and invited him to come the next day to hear the account of the third.
column3: Thus Sindbad ended the relation of the second voyage, gave Hindbad another hundred sequins, and invited him to come the next day to hear the account of the third.

column2: CHAPTER VIII
column3: CHAPTER eight

column2: THE WHITE CAT
column3: THE WHITE CAT

column2: There was once a king who had three sons, all remarkably handsome in their persons, and in their tempers brave and noble.
column3: There was once a king who had three sons, all remarkably handsome in their persons, and in their tempers brave and noble.

column2: Some wicked courtiers made the king believe that the princes were impatient to wear the crown, and that they were contriving a plot to deprive him of his sceptre and his kingdom.
column3: Some wicked courtiers made the king believe that the princes were impatient to wear the crown, and that they were contriving a plot to deprive him of his sceptre and his kingdom.

column2: The king felt he was growing old; but as he found himself as capable of governing as he had ever been, he had no inclination to resign his power; and therefore, that he might pass the rest of his days peaceably, he determined to employ the princes in such a manner, as at once to give each of them the hope of succeeding to the crown, and fill up the time they might otherwise spend in so undutiful a manner.
column3: The king felt he was growing old; but as he found himself as capable of governing as he had ever been, he had no inclination to resign his power; and therefore, that he might pass the rest of his days peaceably, he determined to employ the princes in such a manner, as at once to give each of them the hope of succeeding to the crown, and fill up the time they might otherwise spend in so undutiful a manner.

column2: He sent for them to his cabinet, and after conversing with them kindly, he added: "You must be sensible, my dear children, that my great age prevents me from attending so closely as I have hitherto done to state affairs.
column3: He sent for them to his cabinet, and after conversing with them kindly, he added: "You must be sensible, my dear children, that my great age prevents me from attending so closely as I have hitherto done to state affairs.

column2: I fear this may be injurious to my subjects; I therefore desire to place my crown on the head of one of you, but it is no more than just, that in return for such a present, you should procure me some amusement in my retirement, before I leave the Capital for ever.
column3: I fear this may be injurious to my subjects; I therefore desire to place my crown on the head of one of you, but it is no more than just, that in return for such a present, you should procure me some amusement in my retirement, before I leave the Capital for ever.

column2: I cannot help thinking, that a little dog, that is handsome, faithful, and engaging, would be the very thing to make me happy; so that without bestowing a preference on either of you, I declare that he who brings me the most perfect little dog shall be my successor." The princes were much surprised at the fancy of their father to have a little dog, yet they accepted the proposition with pleasure: and accordingly, after taking leave of the king, who presented them with abundance of money and jewels, and appointed that day twelvemonth for their return, they set off on their travels.
column3: I cannot help thinking, that a little dog, that is handsome, faithful, and engaging, would be the very thing to make me happy; so that without bestowing a preference on either of you, I declare that he who brings me the most perfect little dog shall be my successor." The princes were much surprised at the fancy of their father to have a little dog, yet they accepted the proposition with pleasure: and accordingly, after taking leave of the king, who presented them with abundance of money and jewels, and appointed that day twelvemonth for their return, they set off on their travels.
